image.altText: An SES volunteer in orange overalls walks across grassland towards a row of SES and police vehicles

props.synopsis: SA Police say "time is of the essence" in their search for a four-year-old boy who has been missing from his family's homestead in South Australia's mid-north since Saturday evening.

title.children: Police horses and water operations join 'extensive' search for missing 4yo

image.altText: A woman with a serious expression stands in front of posters on a wall

props.synopsis: SA Police conducted more than 1,600 metal detector searches at Burnside Village at the weekend, but the state's Guardian for Children and Young People says officials need to "get the balance right" amid a crackdown on knife crime.

title.children: Youth guardian calls for balance amid SA knife crime crackdown

props.synopsis: Robert Hall was killed when he was struck by partially blind driver John Charles Robertson on the Horrocks Highway in 2018. His family feel their pleas for licence reforms have been ignored by the state government.

title.children: Grieving family's anger at lack of licence reform amidst government 'buck-passing'

image.altText: Close up photo of a southern pygmy perch in a human hand.

props.synopsis: Information gleaned from tiny growth rings on "ear bones" of native pygmy perch could be the key to bringing them back from local extinction in the lower Murray.Â

title.children: Rings on 'ear stones' helping re-establish native pygmy fish

image.altText: A woman with short, curly grey hair stands next to a box planter pouring water from a green watering can.

props.synopsis: Dead sea life washed ashore during SA's marine algal bloom has been diverted into commercial compost for farms and gardens, in what has been viewed as a small win amid the large-scale devastation.

title.children: Algal bloom sea casualties find new life in commercial compost

image.altText: A dolphin mid-air with water splashing under it

props.synopsis: The "completely preventable" death of a three-year-old dolphin in Adelaide's Port River has prompted new calls for mandatory propeller guards on boats entering the sanctuary.

title.children: 'A huge amount of sadness': Orphaned dolphin killed in Adelaide's Port River

image.altText: Jesse Wardlaw shrugs and smiles as she celebrates a goal in an AFLW game.

props.synopsis: St Kilda outscores Port Adelaide 38-0 in the final quarter after trailing by 27 points at three-quarter-time, while Ally Anderson and Ebony Marinoff become the first players to feature in 100 AFLW games.

title.children: Saints pull off record comeback win as AFLW stars celebrate centuries

image.altText: A dark-coloured feral pig on some grass near a patch of mud.

props.synopsis: Dozens of pigs were released illegally over several attempts to establish populations for hunting, with a local landscape board warning of the danger a feral population could cause.

title.children: Feral pigs found in SA were imported illegally from NSW, testing shows

image.altText: Steam engine crossing a railway bridge.

props.synopsis: Forget about being crammed on a suburban train, the real romance of rail is found through luxury long-distance inland trips or journeys back in time.

title.children: Australia's top rail journeys for tourists wanting to take it all in

image.altText: An image of two men composited next to each other. They both wear suits. One has short dark hair, the other has grey.

props.synopsis: South Australia's algal bloom continues to cause political headaches for state and federal Labor. Perhaps that's why scientists are copping some of the flak now.

title.children: As algal bloom recriminations grow, politicians point to the scientists

image.altText: A man with blond hair and a blue sweat band standing in front of the sea link ferry.

props.synopsis: Nicholas Tremaine is cycling more than 40,000 kilometres to raise $1 million to fight the condition that's befallen his mother and is now Australia's leading cause of death.

title.children: Cyclist's gruelling fundraising mission to raise dementia awareness

image.altText: A man in a suit stands behind a lectern with media microphones on it. To his left is a woman holding a piece of paper

props.synopsis: South Australia's Premier says the government is grappling with whether it should give daily updates on the bloom's location during summer, and says it has been "actively engaged" in conversations with the federal government since its emergence.Â

title.children: SA government grapples with whether it should issue daily bloom updates during summer

image.altText: A young Indigenous teen girl points with a pointer in a classroom

props.synopsis: Jaz Fusi has been passionate about learning Paakantyi language for most of her life. Now, she teaches it to her local school's teachers and is eager to see other kids do the same.

title.children: Teenage student becomes Indigenous language teacher at outback NSW school

image.altText: A mans hand holds a curved knife, it has a blue pointed blade and knuckle shaped handle, with a hold for thumb in it

props.synopsis: SA Police has announced Declared Public Precincts at eight shopping centres in metropolitan Adelaide, with a knife discovered in the first 15 minutes of a patrol at Marion Shopping Centre.

title.children: Knife found on first day of expanded police powers at shopping centres in Adelaide

image.altText: A dead shark lies on the sand of a beach

props.synopsis: Investigations into nine white shark deaths this year have revealed at least three are likely to have been killed by the toxic algal bloom. Warning: This story contains images that some readers may find distressing.

title.children: At least three shark deaths linked to algal bloom, report shows

image.altText: Man standing with hand on hip at the front of the Adelaide Magistrates Court

props.synopsis: A well-known Adelaide tailor has been issued a fine by the Adelaide Magistrates Court for smoking outside his CBD business to cope with stress.

title.children: Tailor fined for smoking outside Adelaide CBD business

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas is wearing a blue suit with a white button up shirt with cameras pointing at him

props.synopsis: The debate over Santos's Narrabri gas project reignites, with traditional owners condemning 'disgraceful' comments made by two state premiers.

title.children: Traditional owners slam SA premier for 'disgraceful' call on Santos gas project

image.altText: A rabbit.

props.synopsis:
A teacher and a librarian banned from working with children after they were charged with ill-treating animals have lost a bid to have the ban rescinded.Â 

Â

title.children: Teacher and librarian accused of animal cruelty lose bid to continue working with kids

image.altText: a woman stands in front of two old gum trees which are fenced off, she is looking to her left and the sun is shining on her face

props.synopsis: Kylie Soanes says urban development should not come at the expense of nature and there's no reason why we should not spot a fairy wren on the way to the bus stop.

title.children: One woman's mission to rewild our cities

image.altText: pills

props.synopsis: The TGA has urged patients to stop using unregulated melatonin products after testing revealed âsignificant discrepanciesâ between their actual melatonin amount and what was on the label.

title.children: Melatonin product has 400 per cent more than advertised, regulator warns

image.altText: Tylere Baker-Pearce outside court

props.synopsis: Tylere Baker-Pearce, 39, was arrested by counterterrorism police outside a Brisbane court on Monday.

title.children: Man charged with giving Nazi salute at the AFL facing two new counts

image.altText: A group of rescuers wearing bright orange coats and with bushwalking packs on their backs stand in a group.

props.synopsis: Cradle Mountain is one of Tasmania's most popular, and dangerous, tourism destinations. After another tragedy, questions are asked about what more could be done to ensure the safety of visitors.

title.children: After another Cradle Mountain death, how can tourists be better prepared?

image.altText: Signage at an Optus store in Melbourne

props.synopsis: Embattled telco Optus has apologised for a network outage that led to nine failed triple-0 calls near Wollongong on the NSW south coast over the weekend.

title.children: Optus investigates more failed triple-0 calls in NSW outage

image.altText: a pink pub with a sign saying 'larrimah hotel'

props.synopsis: The Larrimah Hotel sells to an Alice Springs businesswoman, after capturing the world's attention in podcasts and films about the disappearance 70-year-old Paddy Moriarty.

title.children: Owner sells outback pub shrouded in mystery after 70yo's disappearance

image.altText: Annette Brennan Lagi

props.synopsis: 47-year-old Stephen Fleming, who has pleaded guilty to manslaughter, is accused of ending his new housemate's life last year and stuffing the English teacher's body in a green waste bin.

title.children: Killer was 'extremely callous' in dumping victim's body

image.altText: Will Ashcroft of the Lions is presented the Norm Smith Medal

props.synopsis: Brisbane Lions midfield star Will Ashcroft has added the AFL coaches' award for player of the finals to his growing list of accolades in the wake of his team's 47-point victory over the Geelong Cats on Saturday.

title.children: Ashcroft accolades grow after being named the best player of AFL finals

image.altText: Bright flowers at the Victoria Police Memorial in the Kings Domain Gardens, Melbourne.

props.synopsis: Three police officers shot dead in the line of duty this year are being honoured as part of National Police Remembrance Day services around Australia.

title.children: National services remember fallen officers as Porepunkah manhunt wound back

image.altText: A Caboolture Hospital sign.

props.synopsis: A clinical team is reviewing the medical imaging results of up to 9,000 patients at Caboolture Hospital amid concerns about how results were communicated.

title.children: Thousands of medical scans at Qld hospital may not have been properly reviewed

image.altText: twisted corrugated metal sheets and poles fall and lie on top of a dented red hatchback and cover grey car

props.synopsis: At least nine people have died after heavy rain and strong winds from the former Typhoon Bualoi flooded roads, knocked off roofs in central Vietnam, state media reported, with residents describing it as "one of the strongest".

title.children: At least nine dead after Typhoon Bualoi makes landfall in Vietnam

image.altText: An official removes the winners' trophy from the presentation area

props.synopsis: India T20 skipper Suryakumar Yadav has claimed that his team was denied the chance to lift the 2025 Asia Cup trophy, after it beat Pakistan in the final by five wickets on Sunday.

title.children: India claim they were denied Asia Cup trophy after win over Pakistan

image.altText: Noemie Fox in action during an Australian Canoe Slalom team training session

props.synopsis: Noemie Fox has just missed out on a dream start to the ICF Slalom World Championships, finishing fifth in the kayak cross time trials.

title.children: Noemie Fox leads Aussies to kick off ICF Slalom World Championships

image.altText: Back of woman in black top and jeans with long dark hair arms outstretched on stage in front of packed room hands in the air

props.synopsis: Astrid Jorgensen has an unusual condition â she finds many human noises unbearable. So how did she end up running the "world's biggest choir"?

title.children: Astrid tried to be a nun. Instead, she created one of our biggest music acts

image.altText: An aerial shot looking down at a police car and two people standing nearby.

props.synopsis: A crime scene has been declared at Kenmore Hills after two people were found dead at a property just after midday on Monday.

title.children: Police are investigating the death of two people in Brisbane's west

image.altText: A close-up of the directions on a small bottle of pepper spray.

props.synopsis: Security guards at a Darwin nightclub have been confronted with pepper spray two weekends in a row, during the first month of a Northern Territory-wide trial of the weapons.

title.children: Union labels pepper spray trial 'dangerous' after two incidents in two weeks

image.altText: A young girl jumping on a mattress on a red dirt ground.

props.synopsis: Many Aboriginal people in Tennant Creek live in overcrowded makeshift shelters with no running water or electricity, as they wait up to a decade for a home. But experts say the social housing being built is not safe for the climate of today, let alone into the future.

title.children: These Australians are homeless with a house
